div.p: S. I rejoice that you have been restored to us; for I was deeply grieved when I learned from my brother's recent letters that you were not in good health.
At the same time, Mr. Musculus was also suffering here, so much so that I greatly feared for his life; but he too has been restored by the grace of the Lord.
May the Lord preserve both of you for us as long as possible! In the meantime, I received what you sent through Dumysius, and I thank you for them.

I am also returning the same through him, as you requested, along with those letters you wrote to me about the Savoyard matter; I did not want to keep them, as I saw that they were so eagerly and repeatedly requested by you.
You have reasons that are not to be despised; however, we fear that what you most desire, namely a constant and perpetual peace, may not be obtained.
Many good men fear that whatever is done will lead to the suppression of the Genevans, and they themselves sense this; therefore, as far as I understand, they abhor that pacification.
I do not yet know what the envoys here are going to achieve.
The day before yesterday they were heard by the senate, and yesterday by the dioceses; but they received no other response than what they had previously received at Baden.
Therefore, they requested to be heard again today.
What that is or what should be answered, I do not yet know.
The citizens are very much at odds with each other, and I fear disturbances among us, which the Lord may graciously avert.
A certain song, not without wit, was found by the consul himself these days, written against those peacemakers; it greatly disturbed the senate; however, the author cannot be found.

As for Sulcer's business, I have not been able to discuss it with our people these days due to the presence of those envoys; however, I have discussed it with Mr. Dumysius; he will act with our people.
I was grieved that he was summoned to the senate; for he seemed to have satisfied most people.
Now I see that this was good, as he was thus caught in a lie, and I do not doubt that our people will be very reluctant to bear this and will agree to send letters to the people of Basel.
Would that he could be removed from there and the church of Basel be purged of this leaven! Various reports are coming from France.
Someone recently returned from Lyon said that the English, having made peace, had left Normandy; now it is reported that they are proceeding bravely and inflicting many defeats on the French.
Thus, nothing is certain to me here.
All of ours greet you in return, Treasurer Haller, Musculus, my father-in-law, brothers, and all fellow ministers.
Give my regards to all of yours in my name.
Bern, August 14, 1563.
Johannes Haller, forever yours.
To the most illustrious man, Mr. Heinrich Bullinger, the most faithful pastor of the church in Zurich, my honorable lord and dearest compatriot.
Mr. Heinrich Bullinger in Zurich.
